Previous Next

Rulesïƒ

Rules are the deduction rules that allow, from a given set of true facts, the derivation of new ones. Each rule asks for a collection of arguments, demanded by its premise predicates, that has to be â€œmatchedâ€. Next, the rule is â€œappliedâ€, at which point the corresponding predicate is added to the proof state.

As a standard, rules are labelled in order (r00 to r49), but some rules have more specific names, for readability. The naming shows in the proof step, as the reason a proof step is true.

Legacy rulesïƒ

r00 : Perpendiculars give parallelïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}AB \perp CD\\ CD \perp EF \\ABE \text{ non-collinear}\end{cases} \implies AB \parallel EF\)

Two lines AB, EF, that are orthogonal to a same line CD are parallel to one another.

r01 : Definition of circleïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(|OA|=|OB|=|OC|=|OD|\implies ABCD\text{ on a circle}\)

Four points A, B, C, D equidistant from a center O all lie on a same circle. (One side of the definition of a circle.)

r02 : eqangle2paraïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\angle (AB \times PQ)=\angle (CD \times PQ)\implies AB \parallel CD\)

If two lines AB and CD define the same angle with respect to a fixed transverse line PQ, they are parallel.

r03 : cyclic2eqangleïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(ABPQ\text{ on a circle}\implies \angle (PA\times PB)=\angle (QA\times QB)\)

Two angles with the vertices P, Q on a circle that determine the same arc AB on that same circle are congruent.

r04 : eqangle2cyclicïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\angle (PA\times PB)=\angle (QA\times QB) \implies ABPQ\text{ on a circle}\)

Reverse direction of r03: If P, Q are vertices of congruent angles, and A and B are the intersections of the legs of the angles with vertices P and Q, there is a circle through A, B, P, and Q.

r05 : eqangle_on_circle2congïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}ABCPQR\text{ on a circle}\\ \angle (CA\times CB)=\angle (RP\times RQ)\end{cases}\implies |AB|=|PQ|\)

From r03, two congruent angles on a circle determine arcs on that circle of the same length. This rule says that arcs of the same length determine chords of the same length on the same circle.

r06 : Base of half triangleïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}E\text{ midpoint of } AB\\ F\text{ midpoint of }AC\end{cases} \implies EF \parallel BC\)

The line connecting the midpoints of two sides of a triangle is parallel to the third side of the same triangle. (This is a special instance of Thalesâ€™ Theorem with â€œmidpointâ€ predicates).

r07 : para2eqratio3ïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}AB\parallel CD\\ OAC \text{ collinear}\\ OBD\text{ collinear}\end{cases}\implies \begin{cases}\frac{OA}{OC}=\frac{OB}{OD}\\ \frac{AO}{AC}=\frac{BO}{BD}\\ \frac{OC}{AC}=\frac{OD}{BD}\end{cases}\)

This is an instance of Thalesâ€™s theorem, saying that two parallel lines AB and CD cut by two intersecting transverse lines AC and BD, will determine a collection of proportional segments.

r08 : perp_perp2eqangleïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(AB \perp CD \wedge EF \perp GH \implies \angle (AB\times EF) = \angle (CD\times GH)\)

r09 : Sum of angles of a triangleïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}\angle (AB\times CD)=\angle (MN\times PQ)\\ \angle (CD\times EF)=\angle (PQ\times RU)\end{cases}\implies \angle(AB\times EF)=\angle(MN\times RU)\)

This rule says that if two triangles have two pairs of congruent angles, the third pair of angles will be congruent as well. It is a non-numerical version of the statement that the angles of a triangle always add to a given constant.

r10 : Ratio cancellationïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

(Just a multiplication)

\(\frac{AB}{CD} = \frac{MN}{PQ} \wedge \frac{CD}{EF} = \frac{PQ}{RU} \implies \frac{AB}{EF} = \frac{MN}{RU}\)

This is a simple algebraic fact: if you multiply the two equalities from the hypothesis together, there will be a cancellation of numerators and denominators giving you the consequence.

r11 : eqratio2angle_bisectorïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}\frac{DB}{DC} = \frac{AB}{AC} \\DBC\text{ collinear} \end{cases}\implies \angle (AB\times AD)=\angle(AD\times AC)\)

r12 : Bisector theoremïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}\angle (AB\times AD) = \angle (AD\times AC) \\ DBC\text{ collinear}\end{cases} \implies \frac{DB}{DC} = \frac{AB}{AC}\)

r13 : Isosceles triangle equal anglesïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(|OA|=|OB| \implies \angle (OA\times AB) = \angle (AB\times OB)\)

The theorem says that the base angles of an isosceles triangle are congruent.

r14 : Equal base angles imply isoscelesïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\angle (AO\times AB) = \angle (BA\times BO) \implies |OA|=|OB|\)

This is the reverse direction of r13, saying that if the base angles of a triangle are congruent, the triangle is isosceles.

r15 : circle_perp2eqangleïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases} O\text{ center of circle }ABC \\ OA \perp AX\end{cases} \implies \angle (AX\times AB) = \angle (CA\times CB)\)

r16 : circle_eqangle2perpïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases} O\text{ center of circle }ABC \\ \angle (AX\times AB)=\angle(CA\times CB)\end{cases} \implies OA\perp AX\)

r17 : circle_midp2eqangleïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases} O\text{ center of circle }ABC \\ M\text{ midpoint of }BC\end{cases} \implies \angle(AB\times AC)=\angle(OB\times OM)\)

r18 : eqangle2midpïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases} O\text{ center of circle }ABC \\ MBC\text{ collinear}\\ \angle(AB\times AC)=\angle(OB\times OM)\end{cases} \implies M\text{ midpoint of }BC\)

r19 : Hypothenuse is diameterïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}AB\perp BC \\ M\text{ midpoint of}AC\end{cases} \implies |AM|=|BM|\)

This rule says that the hypothenuse of a right triangle is a diameter of its circumcircle, or that the midpoint of the hypothenuse is the circumcenter of the right triangle.

r20 : Diameter is hypotenuseïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}O \text{ center of the circle } ABC \\ OAC\text{ collinear} \end{cases}\implies AB \perp BC\)

This theorem is the reverse direction of r19. It says that if two points are the edges of the diameter of a circle, and at the same time are vertices of an inscribed triangle, the triangle has a right angle at the third vertex.

r21 : cyclic_para2eqangleïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}ABCD\text{ on a circle} \\ AB \parallel CD\end{cases} \implies \angle (AD\times CD) = \angle (CD\times CB)\)

r22 : Bisector Constructionïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}M \text{ midpoint of }AB \\ OM\perp AB \end{cases} \implies |OA|=|OB|\)

This rule says that the perpendicular line through the midpoint of the segment is the perpendicular bisector of the segment (the locus of all equidistant points to the vertices of the segment).

r23 : Bisector is perpendicularïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(|AP|=|BP| \wedge |AQ|=|BQ| \implies AB\perp PQ\)

This rule is the reverse direction of r22. It says that the locus of the points that are equidistant to the two vertices of a segment AB is a straight line perpendicular to AB.

r24 : cong_cyclic2perpïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}|AP|=|BP| \\ |AQ|=|BQ| \\ ABPQ\text{ on a circle}\end{cases} \implies PA\perp AQ\)

r25 : midp2paraïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}M\text{ midpoint of }AB \\M \text{ midpoint of }CD\end{cases} \implies AC \parallel BD\)

r26 : Diagonals of parallelogramïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}M \text{ midpoint of }AB \\ AC \parallel BD \\ AD \parallel BC \end{cases}\implies M \text{ midpoint of }CD\)

r27 : eqratio_sameside2paraïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}\frac{OA}{AC}=\frac{OB}{BD}\\ OAC\text{ collinear}\\OBD\text{ collinear}\\ OAC\text{ has the same orientation as }BOD\implies AB\parallel CD\end{cases}\implies AB\parallel CD\)

r28 : para2collïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(AB \parallel AC \implies ABC\text{ collinear}\)

r29 : midp2eqratioïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases} M \text{ midpoint of }AB \\ N\text{ midpoint of } CD \end{cases}\implies \frac{MA}{AB} = \frac{NC}{CD}\)

r30 : eqangle_perp2perpïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}\angle (AB\times PQ)=\angle (CD\times UV) \\ PQ\perp UV \end{cases}\implies AB\perp CD\)

r31 : eqratio_cong2congïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\frac{AB}{PQ} = \frac{CD}{UV} \wedge |PQ| = |UV| \implies |AB| = |CD|\)

r32 : cong_cong2contriïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}|AB| = |PQ| \\ |BC| = |QR| \\ |CA| = |RP|\end{cases}\implies \Delta ABC\cong^\ast \Delta PQR\)

r33 : cong_eqangle2contriïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}|AB| = |PQ| \\ |BC| = |QR| \\ \angle (BA\times BC) = \angle (QP\times QR)\end{cases}\implies \Delta ABC\cong^\ast\Delta PQR\)

r34 : eqangle2simtriïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}\angle (BA\times BC) = \angle (QP\times QR) \\ \angle (CA\times CB) = \angle (RP\times RQ)\end{cases}\implies \Delta ABC\sim \Delta PQR\)

r35 : eqangle2simtri2ïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}\angle (BA\times BC) = \angle (QR\times QP) \\ \angle (CA\times CB) = \angle (RQ\times RP)\end{cases}\implies \Delta ABC\sim^2 \Delta PQR\)

r36 : eqangle_cong2contriïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}\angle (BA\times BC) = \angle (QP\times QR) \\ \angle (CA\times CB) = \angle (RP\times RQ)\\ |AB| = |PQ| \\ ABC\text{ non-collinear} \end{cases}\implies \Delta ABC\cong \Delta PQR\)

r37 : eqangle_cong2contriïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}\angle (BA\times BC) = \angle (QP\times QR) \\ \angle (CA\times CB) = \angle (RP\times RQ)\\ |AB| = |PQ| \\ ABC\text{ non-collinear} \end{cases}\implies \Delta ABC\cong^2 \Delta PQR\)

r38 : eqratio_eqangle2simtriïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}\frac{BA}{BC} = \frac{QP}{QR} \\ \frac{CA}{CB} = \frac{RP}{RQ}\\ ABC\text{ non-collinear} \end{cases}\implies \Delta ABC\sim^\ast \Delta PQR\)

r39 : eqratio_eqangle2simtriïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}\frac{BA}{BC} = \frac{QP}{QR} \\ \angle (BA\times BC)\rangle = \angle (QP\times QR)\\ ABC\text{ non-collinear}\end{cases} \implies \Delta ABC\sim^\ast \Delta PQR\)

r40 : eqratio_eqratio_cong2contriïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}\frac{BA}{BC} = \frac{QP}{QR} \\ \frac{CA}{CB} = \frac{RP}{RQ}\\ ABC\text{ non-collinear} \\ |AB| = |PQ|\end{cases}\implies ABC\cong^\ast PQR\)

r41 : para2eqratioïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}AB\parallel CD \\ MAD\text{ collinear} \\ NBC \text{ collinear} \\ \frac{MA}{MD}=\frac{NB}{NC}\\ MAD \text{ has the same orientation as }NBC \end{cases}\implies MN\parallel A B\)

r42 : eqratio62paraïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}AB\parallel CD \\ MAD\text{ collinear} \\ NBC\text{ collinear}\end{cases}\implies \frac{MA}{MD}=\frac{NB}{NC}\)

New rulesïƒ

r43 : Orthocenter theoremïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(AB\perp CD \wedge AC\perp BD\implies AD\perp BC\)

r44 : Pappusâ€™s theoremïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}ABC\text{ collinear} \\ PQR\text{ collinear} \\ XAQ\text{ collinear}\\ XPB\text{ collinear} \\ YAR\text{ collinear} \\ YPC\text{ collinear}\\ ZBR\text{ collinear} \\ ZCQ\text{ collinear}\end{cases}\implies XYZ\text{ collinear}\)

r45 : Simson line theoremïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases} ABCP\text{ on a circle} \\ ALC\text{ collinear} \\ PL\perp AC\\ \text{coll}(M, B, C) \\ PM\perp BC\\ NAB\text{ collinear} \\ PN\perp AB\end{cases}\implies LMN\text{ collinear}\)

r46 : Incenter theoremïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}\angle(AB\times AX)=\angle (AX\times AC) \\ \angle(BA\times BX)=\angle (BX\times BC)\\ ABC\text{ non-collinear}\end{cases}\implies \angle (CB\times CX)=\angle (CX\times CA)\)

r47 : Circumcenter theoremïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}M\text{ midpoint of }AB \\ XM\perp AB \\ N\text{ midpoint of }BC\\ XN\perp BC \\ P\text{ midpoint of }CA\end{cases}\implies XP\perp CA\)

r48 : Centroid theoremïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}M\text{ midpoint of }AB \\ MXC\text{ collinear}\\ N\text{ midpoint of }BC \\ NXC\text{ collinear}\\ P\text{ midpoint of }CA\end{cases}\implies XPB\text{ collinear}\)

r49 : Recognize center of cyclic (circle)ïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}O\text{ center of the circle }ABC \\ABCD\text{ on a circle}\end{cases}\implies OA= OD\)

r50 : Recognize center of cyclic (cong)ïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

\(\begin{cases}ABCD\text{ on a circle}\\ OA=OB\\ OC=OD\\ AB\not\parallel CD\end{cases}\implies OA=OC\)

r51 : Midpoint splits in twoïƒ

Figure

Formal Statement

Description

(Feeds algebraic module)

\(M\text{ midpoint of AB}\implies \frac{MA}{AB}=\frac{1}{2}\)

This rule converts a symbolic statement (M is the midpoint of AB) into an algebraic one (the ratio between AM and AB is 1/2). This allows AR to process information from midpoints.
